qas.question: On what date did most European countries set the start of the new year?
When did Scotland begin to use January 1 as the start of the new year?
When did the other British states and colonies set the year start date to January 1?
What act did Britain use to implement the use of the Gregorian calendar?
When did England finally change the tax year to 6 April?

plausible_answers.text: changed the start of the year to 1 January

qas.question: What do most European countries do after they adopted the Gregorian calendar?
What country changed the new year to January 1 during the sixteenth century

plausible_answers.text: England, Ireland and the British colonies

qas.question: Who changed the start of the new year to January 1 during the seventeenth century?
What was the name of the act that changed the start of the year and a seventeenth century?
What remained on March 25 in Scotland?

context: Most Western European countries <b5_0>changed the start of the year to <a0_0>1 January<b5_0/><a0_0/> before they adopted the Gregorian calendar. For example, <b6_0>Scotland<b6_0/> changed the start of the Scottish New Year to 1 January in <a1_0>1600<a1_0/> (this means that 1599 was a short year). <b7_0>England, Ireland and the British colonies<b7_0/> changed the start of the year to 1 January in <a2_0>1752<a2_0/> (so 1751 was a short year with only 282 days) though in England the <b9_0>start of the tax year<b9_0/> remained at 25 March (O.S.), 5 April (N.S.) till <a4_0>1800<a4_0/>, when it moved to 6 April. Later in 1752 in September the Gregorian calendar was introduced throughout Britain and the British colonies (see the section Adoption). These two reforms were implemented by the <a3_0><b8_0>Calendar (New Style) Act 1750<a3_0/>.
